questions.text: Which of the following is not a long-acting reversible contraceptive method? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Laparoscopic tubal ligation


Laparoscopic tubal ligation is a permanent form of contraception and is not classified as a long-acting reversible contraceptive (LARC). It involves the surgical closure or blocking of the fallopian tubes to prevent pregnancy permanently.

 

Long-acting reversible contraceptive (LARC) methods are effective for extended periods and can be reversed if desired. They include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper T: Correct. Copper T is an intrauterine device (IUD) that can provide contraception for several years.

 

Option B. Implanon: Correct. Implanon is a type of contraceptive implant that provides effective contraception for several years.

 

Option D. SC DMPA: This is a LARC. It is a sub cutaneous preparation of depot medroxy progesterone acetate and is administered once in 3 months

 

Educational Objective:


Laparoscopic tubal ligation is a permanent method of contraception and is not a long-acting reversible contraceptive (LARC).

questions.text: "Vasopressin escape" in SIADH results due to: (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Downregulation of aquaporin 2 production

 

Vasopressin escape in SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion) results due to downregulation of aquaporin 2 production.

 

Downregulation of aquaporin-2 receptors occurs due to prolonged exposure to elevated vasopressin levels resulting in excessive reabsorption of water, despite high serum ADH levels, thus maintaining euvolemia and preventing excessive dilutional hyponatremia in SIADH. This is called as vasopressin escape.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in urine osmolarity: Incorrect. Vasopressin escape does not result in an increase in urine osmolarity. Instead, it is characterized by the body's ability to excrete free water to prevent hyponatremia.

 

Option C. Decrease in ADH secretion: Incorrect. Vasopressin escape occurs despite high levels of ADH, not due to a decrease in ADH secretion.

 

Option D. Upregulation of aquaporin 2 production: Incorrect. The condition involves the downregulation, not upregulation, of aquaporin 2 production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syndrome of inappropriate anti-diuretic hormone (SIADH): Pathogenesis and clinical findings

questions.text: Which of the following enhances iron absorption? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin C

 

Option B: Vitamin C (Ascorbic acid) – Correct Answer

  • Enhances iron absorption by:
    • Reducing ferric iron (Fe³⁺) to ferrous iron (Fe²⁺) — the absorbable form.
    • Forms soluble complexes with iron in the gut, preventing precipitation.
       

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Vitamin A: While important for overall health, it does not directly enhance iron absorption.

 

Option C. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Essential for carbohydrate metabolism, but it does not affect iron absorption.

 

Option D. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Important for various metabolic processes but does not directly enhance iron absorption.

 

Educational Objective

 

Vitamin C enhances iron absorption by reducing ferric ions (Fe+++) to ferrous ions (Fe++) and forming a chelate that protects iron from oxidation, thereby facilitating its absorption in the intestine.

questions.text: Like all the opioids, tramadol acts as an analgesic drug by stimulating mu opioid receptors. Apart from this, the additional analgesic mechanism of tramadol is? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Serotonin and nor-adrenaline reuptake inhibition

 

Tramadol is an atypical opioid analgesic that not only acts by stimulating mu opioid receptors, like other opioids, but also has an additional mechanism of action. This dual mechanism contributes to its analgesic effect.

 

  • Mu Opioid Receptor Agonism: Tramadol binds to mu opioid receptors, which are part of the body's endogenous pain relief system. Activation of these receptors leads to pain relief.
  • Serotonin and Noradrenaline Reuptake Inhibition: Unlike typical opioids, tramadol also inhibits the reuptake of serotonin (5-HT) and noradrenaline (NA). This increases the levels of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft, enhancing their action. This mechanism activates the monoaminergic descending inhibitory pathways in the spinal cord, which further contributes to pain relief.

 

Due to its unique mechanism, tramadol's analgesic action is only partially reversed by naloxone, an opioid antagonist, indicating that non-opioid mechanisms also play a significant role in its pain-relieving effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anticholinergic: Tramadol does not have anticholinergic properties. Anticholinergic drugs block the action of acetylcholine in the brain and are not related to the analgesic mechanism of tramadol.

 

Option C. Antihistaminic: Tramadol does not act as an antihistamine. Antihistamines are used primarily to treat allergic reactions and have no significant role in pain relief through histamine receptor antagonism.

 

Option D. Serotonin and dopamine reuptake inhibition: While tramadol does inhibit serotonin reuptake, it does not inhibit dopamine reuptake significantly. Its main additional mechanism of analgesia is through the inhibition of serotonin and noradrenaline reuptake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tramadol provides pain relief not only through mu opioid receptor agonism but also by inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin and noradrenaline, thereby activating the descending inhibitory pain pathways in the spinal cord.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/504

choices.text: Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change

questions.text: Which of the following is not helpful for differentiating between necrosis and apoptosis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Altered cell shape

 

Necrosis and apoptosis are two distinct types of cell death, each with its own characteristics.

 

Altered cell shape: While cell shape can change in both necrosis and apoptosis, it is not a reliable indicator to differentiate between the two. The more useful parameter is cell size: in necrosis, cells swell, whereas in apoptosis, cells shrink. Therefore, altered cell shape is not particularly helpful in distinguishing necrosis from apoptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intact cell organelle: During apoptosis, cell organelles remain intact until the late stages when apoptotic bodies form. These bodies contain tightly packed cytoplasmic components and organelles. In contrast, necrosis is characterized by the breakdown and disintegration of organelles. Thus, the presence of intact organelles helps differentiate apoptosis from necrosis.

 

Option C. Enzyme mediated degradation: This is a hallmark of necrosis. In necrosis, enzymes digest cellular components, leading to the breakdown of organelles and other structures. This feature is not seen in apoptosis, where cellular components are typically preserved until the cell is packaged into apoptotic bodies.

 

Option D. Internal organelle disintegration with lipid change: Necrosis involves the disintegration of organelles and changes in lipids, leading to the loss of cell membrane integrity. This is not a feature of apoptosis, where the membrane remains intact until late stages.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key features to differentiate necrosis from apoptosis include the state of cell organelles (intact in apoptosis, disintegrated in necrosis), enzyme-mediated degradation (present in necrosis), and internal organelle disintegration with lipid changes (present in necrosis). Altered cell shape alone is not a useful parameter for differentiation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman underwent a workup for primary infertility. On hysterosalpingography, there was a bilateral cornual block. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided surgery

 

Cornual block, also known as proximal tubal obstruction, can be effectively managed with proximal tubal catheterization and cannulation, typically guided by hysteroscopy and laparoscopy. This method has about an 85% success rate in restoring tubal patency, making it the next logical step in management for a woman with a bilateral cornual block.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Cornual Block: Proximal tubal obstructions often require intervention to restore patency.
  • Hysteroscopy and Laparoscopy: These procedures allow for precise catheterization and cannulation to open the blocked tubes, leading to a high success rate.
  • Success Rate: Approximately 85% success in restoring tubal patency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuboplasty: While tuboplasty is an option for distal tubal occlusion, it is not the first-line treatment for cornual block.

 

Option C. Hydrotubation: This procedure involves flushing the tubes with fluid but is less effective for treating cornual block compared to hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided surgery. Success rates are poor (15-30 %)

 

Option D. In-vitro fertilization: IVF is typically considered when surgical interventions fail or are not suitable, particularly in women over 35 or those with severe tubal damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cornual block in a young woman with primary infertility should be managed with hysteroscopy and laparoscopy-guided proximal tubal catheterization and cannulation to restore tubal patency before considering more invasive options like IVF.

 

Ref: Page 1158, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph node dissection

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman came with a history of thyroid swelling. FNAC was done and the report was suggestive of papillary carcinoma thyroid. The nodule was "cold" on scan. Which of the following will not be a treatment option for her? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radioiodine ablation of thyroid

 

Radioiodine ablation is typically used after thyroidectomy to eliminate any remaining thyroid tissue and residual cancer cells. However, it is contraindicated during pregnancy due to the risk of harm to the developing fetus from radiation exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total Thyroidectomy: This option involves the complete removal of the thyroid gland and is a standard treatment for papillary thyroid carcinoma. However, the timing of the surgery during pregnancy should be carefully considered in consultation with an experienced healthcare team.

 

Option B. Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph Node Dissection: In cases where there is evidence of lymph node involvement or a high risk of lymph node metastasis, total thyroidectomy with lymph node dissection may be recommended to remove affected lymph nodes in the neck. Again, the timing and extent of surgery should be carefully evaluated during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Right Hemithyroidectomy: Right hemithyroidectomy involves the removal of one lobe (half) of the thyroid gland. This procedure is considered when there is a single, localized thyroid nodule or cancer confined to one side of the thyroid gland. However, for papillary carcinoma thyroid, total thyroidectomy is often preferred to ensure complete removal of the cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radioiodine ablation of thyroid is contraindicated in pregnant women due to risk of radiation exposure to the fetus.

 

Therapeutic uses for Radioactive lodine

 

  1. In primary thyrotoxicosis after the age of 45 years.
  2. In autonomous toxic nodule after 45 years, it is useful as remaining gland will still function adequately after radiotherapy.
  3. In papillary/follicular carcinoma of thyroid, after total thyroidectomy, if there are secondaries elsewhere in the body, as in bones or lungs, then I 131 is given.

questions.text: Macula densa is formed by which part of the nephron? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DCT

 

 

Macula densa is formed by specialized tubular epithelial cells of the distal convoluted tubule. The juxtaglomerular complex consists of macula densa cells in the initial portion of the distal tubule and juxtaglomerular cells in the walls of the afferent and efferent arterioles.

 

The macula densa is a specialized group of epithelial cells in the distal tubules that comes in close contact with the afferent and efferent arterioles. The macula densa cells contain Golgi apparatus, which are intracellular secretory organelles directed toward the arterioles, suggesting that these cells may be secreting a substance toward the arterioles.

 

Tubuloglomerular feedback is the mechanism that regulates GFR through renal tubule and macula densa. When the glomerular filtrate passes through the terminal portion of thick ascending segment, macula densa acts like a sensor. It detects the concentration of sodium chloride in the tubular fluid and accordingly alters the glomerular blood flow and GFR. Macula densa detects the sodium chloride concentration via Na+K+2Cl– cotransporter (NKCC2).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCT (Proximal Convoluted Tubule): Incorrect. The proximal convoluted tubule is involved in the reabsorption of water, ions, and nutrients, but it does not form the macula densa.

 

Option C. Afferent arteriole: Incorrect. The afferent arteriole brings blood into the glomerulus and contains juxtaglomerular cells, but it does not form the macula densa.

 

Option D. Bowman's capsule: Incorrect. Bowman's capsule surrounds the glomerulus and is involved in the initial filtration of blood to form urine but does not form the macula densa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The macula densa, formed by cells of the distal convoluted tubule (DCT), is crucial for sensing sodium chloride concentration in the tubular fluid and regulating glomerular filtration rate (GFR) through the tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism.

questions.text: Match the following parasites with their respective hosts: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1

 

  • Diphyllobothrium latum: Humans (definitive host), Cyclops (first intermediate host), and Fish (second intermediate host).
  • Paragonimus westermani: Humans (definitive host), Snail (first intermediate host), Crayfish and Crab (second intermediate host).
  • Brugia malayi: Humans (definitive host), Mansonia mosquito (intermediate host).
  • Fasciola hepatica: Sheep and Humans (definitive hosts), Snail (first intermediate host), Aquatic vegetation (second intermediate host).

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Identify the instrument: (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Episiotomy scissors

 

Explanation:

 

  • The instrument given in the picture is an episiotomy scissors.
  • The angulation in the scissor is to prevent extension of pelvic tear into the anal margins and obstetric anal sphincter injuries / complete perineal tear.
  • An episiotomy is NOT given routinely.
  • It’s use is restricted and is given in situations like.
    • Macrosomia
    • After coming head of breech
    • Instrumental delivery
    • Shoulder dystocia

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Curved artery: It has serrated tips and ratchet lock . It is used to clamp blood vessels, hold peritoneal edges, tissue dissection

 

 

Option C. Curved mayo scissors: These are used to cut tissue such as the uterus, rectus sheath etc.

 

 

Option D. Mosquito forceps: It is a small artery forceps used to catch small bleeders.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episiotomy scissors are specifically designed with an angulated blade to prevent the extension of pelvic tears into the anal margins, thereby reducing the risk of obstetric anal sphincter injuries and complete perineal tears during childbirth.

 

Ref: Dutta textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 755

questions.text: A patient with O negative and husband B positive delivered a baby. Has received anti-D prophylaxis at 28 weeks. In which of the following conditions will you give anti-D post-delivery? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Baby +ve, DCT -ve

 

In cases where an Rh-negative mother has delivered a baby, the administration of anti-D immunoglobulin post-delivery is crucial if the baby is Rh-positive and the Direct Coombs Test (DCT) is negative.

 

  • Rh incompatibility: The Rh-negative mother may develop antibodies against Rh-positive fetal red blood cells if fetal-maternal hemorrhage occurs. To prevent this alloimmunization and protect future pregnancies, anti-D immunoglobulin is given to neutralize any fetal Rh-positive red blood cells that might have entered the maternal circulation during delivery.
  • Direct Coombs Test (DCT): This test checks whether antibodies are already attached to the baby's red blood cells. A negative DCT indicates that the fetal RBCs are free of maternal antibodies. If the DCT is negative and the baby is Rh-positive, anti-D is administered to the mother to prevent the formation of antibodies in her system.

 

The administration of anti-D within 72 hours of delivery is standard practice to ensure that any fetal red blood cells in the mother’s circulation are neutralized, thereby preventing Rh sensitization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Baby O negative, DCT negative: In this, anti D is not required as the baby's blood group is Rh negative so there is NO risk of isoimmunization

 

Option B. Baby O negative, DCT positive: In this, anti D is not required as the baby's blood group is Rh negative so there is NO risk of iso immunization

 

Option C. Baby Positive, DCT positive: In this patient although the Baby is Rh positive , but DCT is positive which means Abs have already formed in the mother and hence there is no use of giving her Anti D

 

Educational Objective:

 

Administer anti-D immunoglobulin to an Rh-negative mother after delivery if the baby is Rh-positive and the Direct Coombs Test (DCT) is negative to prevent Rh sensitization and protect future pregnancies.

questions.text: Which of the following cerclage procedures would be done in a nonpregnant female? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lash and Lash cerclage

 

Explanation:

 

  • Lash and Lash procedure is the only cerclage procedure that is done in the non-pregnant state. Vaginal procedures are preferred over laparoscopic procedure

 

Types of Cerclage Procedures (Other Options)

 

  1. Transvaginal
  2. Transabdominal

 

1. Transvaginal

 

  • McDonald suture
    • Purse string
    • Below the level of the internal os
    • Placed during pregnancy (12-14 weeks
    • Sutures removed at 37 weeks

 

 

  • Shirodkar cerclage
    • Placed during pregnancy (!2-14 weeks)
    • Bladder pushed up
    • Closer to internal os
    • More physiological than McDonald
    • Usually done if previous failed McDonald
    • A tape is inserted circumferentially near the os
    • Removed at 37 weeks

 

 

  • Wurm’s Cerclage
    • 2 sutures taken as shown in figure
    • Placed during pregnancy at 12-14 weeks
    • Removed at 37 weeks

 

 

  • Lash Cerclage
    • Done PRE-PREGNANCY
    • A defect in cervix is removed and cervix reconstructed
    • Deliver is ALWAYS by LSCS
    • Sutures not removed

 

 

2. Transabdominal:

 

  1. Could be done by laparotomy (1st introduced by Benson and Durfee) OR by Laparoscopy
  2. Preferably done pre-pregnancy but can also be done during pregnancy
  3. Done in cases of failed transvaginal cerclage procedures.
  4. Most physiological as it is highest (at the level of the cervix)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lash and Lash cerclage is the only cerclage procedure done in a nonpregnant female.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best screening investigation for metabolic disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tandem mass spectrometry

 

Tandem Mass Spectrometry

  • Two mass spectrometers (MS) are arranged sequentially.
  • The first MS separates big peptides, based on their mass.
  • From this observation, a single peptide can be directed into the second MS (called parent ion or precursor ion). The parent ion enters the collision cell of the second MS. Here the ions collide with argon gas molecules and are broken into smaller ions. These daughter ions (product ions) are detected and quantified by their mass spectrum in the second instrument.
  • The high selectivity of MS-MS is that the parent ion mass and daughter ion mass are used for characterization.
  • The applications of MS-MS include:
    • Identification and quantification of proteins
    • Drug screening
    • Pesticides
    • Pollutants
    • Screening of inborn errors of metabolism, especially organic acidurias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Western blot:

  • Function: Used for detecting specific proteins in a sample using antibody binding.
  • Limitation: Not suitable for broad metabolic disorder screening; used for protein analysis.

 

Option C. PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction):

  • Function: Amplifies DNA sequences for genetic analysis.
  • Limitation: Highly specific for known genetic mutations; not suitable for comprehensive metabolic screening.

 

Option D. Gel electrophoresis:

  • Function: Separates molecules (DNA, RNA, proteins) based on size and charge.
  • Limitation: Not specific or sensitive enough for broad metabolic disorder screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tandem mass spectrometry (MS/MS) is the preferred method for screening metabolic disorders due to its ability to simultaneously analyze multiple metabolites with high sensitivity and specificity.

questions.text: Identify the site of the lesion: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left occipital lobe

 

  • The visual field defect is right homonymous hemianopia with macular-sparing.
  • It is caused by lesions of the left occipital lobe, which is contralateral/crossing of fibers.
  • Head injury is a common cause of such lesions.
  • These lesions may be associated with visual hallucinations, denial of blindness (Anton syndrome), and the Riddoch phenomenon.
  • These lesions are commonly due to occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery. The part of the occipital lobe representing the peripheral field vision is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.
  • The lesions generally spare the central vision/macular vision since the area at the tip of the calcarine cortex, representing the central macular vision, is supplied by a branch of the middle cerebral artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Occipital Lobe: This would cause a left-sided homonymous hemianopia.

 

Option C. Left Geniculate Body: Lesions here typically produce similar visual field defects as occipital lobe lesions but may have different associated clinical signs and symptoms.

 

Option D. Optic Chiasma: Lesions at the optic chiasm typically produce bitemporal hemianopia, which is not demonstrated in the visual field tests provided.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the left occipital lobe is the most likely cause of the right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing shown in the visual field tests. This understanding is critical for accurately diagnosing the underlying condition, potentially a vascular event, and directing appropriate management and intervention strategies.

questions.text: Which of the following is a function of the marked layer? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium and water retention

 

The image shows the adrenal gland, which is divided into the cortex and the medulla. The cortex is further subdivided into three layers: the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis.

 

  • Zona Glomerulosa: This is the outermost layer of the adrenal cortex and is responsible for the production of mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone. Aldosterone plays a key role in regulating sodium and water balance in the body, leading to sodium retention and water reabsorption in the kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gluconeogenesis: Gluconeogenesis is primarily a function of the zona fasciculata, which secretes glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol) that promote glucose synthesis and metabolism.

 

Option C. Increased sex hormones: The zona reticularis is responsible for producing androgens, which are sex hormones. It does not contribute to sodium and water retention.

 

Option D. Immune cell interaction: While glucocorticoids from the zona fasciculata have some immunosuppressive effects, immune cell interaction is not a primary function of the marked layer, which is the zona glomerulosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex is responsible for sodium and water retention through the secretion of mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone.

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Evaluate the following statements with respect to intertrochanteric fracture: (AIIMS Nov 2019)

 

  1. More common in males than females.
  2. 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  3. It is more commonly associated with nonunion than fracture neck of femur.
  4. 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) b and d are correct.

 

Explanation:

 

INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE FEMUR

 

  • Intertrochanteric fractures are extracapsular fractures of the proximal femur that occur between the greater and lesser trochanter.
  • This metaphyseal region has a more abundant blood supply, contributing to a higher union rate and less osteonecrosis compared to femoral neck fractures.
  • Etiology:
    • These fractures occur both in the elderly and the young, but they are more common in the elderly population with osteoporosis due to a low energy mechanism. 
    • The female to male ration is between 2:1 and 8:1.
    • In the younger population, these fractures typically result from a high-energy mechanism.
  • These patients present with a short and externally rotated limb.
  • Treatment:

 

 

  • Treatment of choice: Dynamic Hip Screw (Undisplaced fracture).
  • Displaced fracture: Proximal femoral nail (Cephalomedullary nail).
  • Latest literature claims better results with Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN).
  • Most common complication is malunion.
  • 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  • 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.

 

INTERTROCHANTERIC FRACTURE VS NECK OF FEMUR FRACTURE

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intertrochanteric fracture is more common in females than males.
  • Most common complication is malunion.
  • 1 year mortality rate is 20-30%.
  • 1 year mortality can be reduced by operating within 48 hours.

choices.text: Rest pain is seen more in the night
Pain in intermittent claudication comes at first step of walking.
The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction

questions.text: Which of the statements regarding claudication pain is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pain in intermittent claudication comes at first step of walking.

 

Intermittent claudication is characterized by muscle pain (ache, cramp, numbness or sense of fatigue), classically in the calf muscle, which occurs during exercise and is relieved by a short period of rest (< 5 minutes). The pain does not typically start with the first step but develops after a predictable distance of walking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rest pain is seen more in the night: True. Rest pain is a more severe symptom of peripheral artery disease (PAD). It typically indicates more advanced disease than intermittent claudication. This pain occurs when the limb is at rest, often at night due to the decreased perfusion that results from the horizontal position of the limb. It often awakens the patient from sleep and can be relieved by hanging the leg over the bed or walking.

 

Option C. Most common cause is atheroma: True. The most common cause of intermittent claudication is atherosclerosis (plaque or atheroma formation) in the peripheral arteries. This reduces blood flow to the muscles during activity, causing pain.

 

Option D. The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction: True. The site of pain (e.g., calf, thigh) does not always directly correlate with the level of arterial obstruction. For instance, while calf pain is often due to femoropopliteal disease, it can also be caused by aortoiliac disease. However, the location of claudication pain can provide a clue to the level of disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incorrect statement among the provided options is that pain in intermittent claudication occurs at the first step of walking.

questions.text: Identify the surgical instrument shown in the image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mixter forceps

 

Mixter forceps is used to clamp the blood vessels and prevent blood loss and pass ligatures and dissect pedicles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adson's forceps: Adson's forceps are used in surgery to manipulate soft tissues such as fascia and skin during suturing.

 

 

Option B. Kocher's forceps: Kocher's forceps is used to clamp the blood vessels and prevent blood loss. It has 2 x 1 teeth at the tip.

 

 

Option D. Rampley forceps: Rampley forceps are used in general surgery to hold swabs and sponges or to grasp tissue. It has a fenestrated tip.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Notochord

 

The marked structure in the image is the notochord, which is a rod-like structure that forms along the midline of the developing embryo. The notochord is derived from the primitive node and extends cranially from the primitive streak. It serves as an embryonic axis, providing structural support and playing a crucial role in the induction of the neural tube formation. Later in development, the notochord largely disappears, but its remnants persist as the nucleus pulposus within the intervertebral discs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primitive streak: Incorrect because the primitive streak appears as a linear structure at the caudal end of the embryo and is the site where epiblast cells migrate to form mesoderm and endoderm. It defines the cranio-caudal axis but is not the central rod-like structure shown in the image.

 

Option C. Neural groove: Incorrect because the neural groove is the midline depression that forms as the neural plate folds inward during neurulation. It is wider and more superficial than the notochord and eventually closes to form the neural tube.

 

Option D. Neural crest cells: Incorrect because neural crest cells are populations of cells that form at the lateral edges of the neural plate and migrate throughout the embryo to form various structures. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The notochord is a midline rod-like structure that induces formation of the neural tube, defines the embryonic axis, and later forms the nucleus pulposus of intervertebral discs.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to treat PCOD? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tamoxifen

 

Explanation:

 

Tamoxifen is not commonly used in the treatment of Polycystic Ovary Disease (PCOD). Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) primarily used in the treatment and prevention of breast cancer.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Medical Management of PCOD:
    • OCP (Option D): Oral contraceptive pills regulate the menstrual cycle and hormones and are given to women who are not desirous of fertility to regularize their cycles.
    • Metformin (Option B): Metformin is an insulin sensitizer, which decreases hyperinsulinemia and improves fertility in patients with PCOD.
    • Ovulation Induction Drugs:
      • Clomiphene (Option A): Clomiphene citrate is commonly used to induce ovulation in women with infertility due to PCOD.
      • Letrozole: Letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, is the drug of choice for ovulation induction in PCOD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clomiphene citrate: Clomiphene is an ovulation induction agent used in the treatment of infertility in women with PCOD.

 

Option B. Metformin: Metformin is used to decrease insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia in PCOD, which can help in regulating menstrual cycles and improving fertility.

 

Option D. OCP: Oral contraceptive pills are used to regulate menstrual cycles and manage hormonal imbalances in women with PCOD who do not seek to become pregnant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen is not typically used in the treatment of PCOD. Instead, treatments include oral contraceptive pills, metformin, and ovulation induction agents such as clomiphene and letrozole.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition. Pg 398 Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th edition pg470

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely regarding Rh incompatibility in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased urine bilirubin

 

Increased urine bilirubin is the least likely finding in newborns with Rh incompatibility. Rh incompatibility occurs when the mother is Rh-negative, and the baby is Rh-positive, leading to hemolysis of the baby's red blood cells. This hemolysis releases hemoglobin, which is broken down into biliverdin and then into unconjugated bilirubin. This unconjugated bilirubin is lipid-soluble and cannot be excreted directly in the urine because it needs to be conjugated by the liver to become water-soluble. However, the enzyme required for this conjugation (glucuronyl transferase) is immature in newborns, especially in those with Rh incompatibility, leading to an accumulation of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood.

 

Unconjugated bilirubin is not excreted in the urine; instead, it is converted to urobilinogen and stercobilinogen in the intestines by bacteria, which are then excreted in the urine and feces, respectively. This process is why increased fecal urobilinogen and stercobilinogen are likely findings in Rh incompatibility. The lack of mature enzyme activity in the liver of a newborn prevents significant conjugation and excretion of bilirubin in the urine, making increased urine bilirubin an unlikely finding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased unconjugated bilirubin: This is a common finding in newborns with Rh incompatibility due to the hemolysis of red blood cells, which leads to the release of hemoglobin that is converted to unconjugated bilirubin.

 

Option B. Increased fecal urobilinogen: This is likely because unconjugated bilirubin, once processed by intestinal bacteria, is converted into urobilinogen and stercobilinogen, which are then excreted in the feces.

 

Option D. Increased stercobilinogen: Like urobilinogen, stercobilinogen is a breakdown product of bilirubin excreted in the feces, making its increase likely in Rh incompatibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Rh incompatibility, increased urine bilirubin is unlikely due to the immaturity of the newborn's liver enzymes needed for bilirubin conjugation.

questions.text: A boy presents with pallor and lymphadenopathy; the X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following drug is not used for the management of the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vincristine

 

  • The X-ray of the skull is showing circumscribed punched out lesions in the skull of a boy whose history reveals the presence of pallor and lymphadenopathy. This is suggestive of Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis.
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is a rare disease in which an excess of immature Langerhans cells (a type of white blood cell) accumulates in various parts of the body, leading to tissue damage and dysfunction.
  • The treatment of LCH depends on the severity and extent of the disease, as well as the age and overall health of the patient. Some cases of LCH can go away on their own, while others require treatment.

 

The main treatment options for LCH include:

 

1. Observation: In some cases, particularly in mild cases that only involve one or a few areas of the body, doctors may recommend monitoring the disease closely without any treatment. The goal is to watch for any changes or progression of the disease and intervene if necessary.

 

2. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy drugs are used to kill the abnormal Langerhans cells and control the disease. Some commonly used chemotherapy drugs for LCH include:

 

  • Vinblastine: Vinblastine is a chemotherapy drug that is often used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children. It works by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells. Vincristine is not recommended for LCH.
  • Methotrexate: Methotrexate is another chemotherapy drug that is commonly used to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.
  • Cladribine: Cladribine is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in more severe cases of LCH that do not respond to other treatments. It works by killing abnormal white blood cells.
  • Etoposide: Etoposide is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the ability of abnormal cells to divide and grow.
  • Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the growth and division of abnormal cells.

 

1. Steroids: Steroids are often used in conjunction with chemotherapy to help reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

 

2. Immunotherapy: Immunotherapy is a newer treatment option that involves using drugs that stimulate the immune system to attack and kill the abnormal cells.

 

3. Surgery: In some cases, surgery may be needed to remove damaged or diseased tissue, particularly if it is causing significant problems or pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Cyclophosphamide: Explanation: Cyclophosphamide is used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH by interfering with the growth and division of abnormal cells.

 

Options B. Methotrexate: Explanation: Methotrexate is used to treat LCH by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.

 

Options C. Vinblastine: Explanation: Vinblastine is commonly used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children, by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells.

 

Options D. Vincristine: Explanation: Vincristine is not recommended for LCH. Other chemotherapy drugs like vinblastine are preferred for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH) is treated with various chemotherapy drugs, but vincristine is not typically used for this condition. Vinblastine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and other drugs are preferred for the management of LCH.

questions.text: The formula for urea clearance is U*V/P, where U is?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine urea in mg /100ml

 

'U' in the urea clearance stands for urine concentration of urea in mg /100ml.

 

The formula for renal clearance of a substance is,

 

Clearance (C = U × V / P),

 

  • U = Urine concentration of the substance in mg / ml
  • V = Urine flow rate in ml/min
  • P = Plasma concentration of substance in mg /ml.

 

Renal clearance of a substance is the volume of plasma that is completely cleared of the substance by the kidneys per unit of time.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Bladder training, with reward for delaying micturition during daytime
Bell and pad based classical conditioning

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presented with complaints of bed-wetting almost twice a week for the past 1 year. A detailed investigation was done to rule out the organic cause. What should be the treatment plan for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bell and pad based classical conditioning

 

This is a first-line behavioral treatment for primary nocturnal enuresis. It involves an alarm that sounds when wetness is detected, conditioning the child to awaken and use the toilet.

 

Other Options:

 

The child described seems to have primary nocturnal enuresis, which is common in children and often has no organic cause:

 

Option A. Pharmacotherapy with imipramine: This is an option, but it's usually reserved for cases that don't respond to first-line treatments because of potential side effects.

 

Option B. Psychodynamic psychotherapy: Not typically used as a first-line treatment for nocturnal enuresis.

 

Option C. Bladder training: This focuses on delaying micturition during daytime, which is beneficial but not considered as the treatment of choice

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sleep related enuresis is defined as voiding of urine at inappropriate places. It is nocturnal in around 80% of cases. The most common cause of bed wetting are psychosocial such as sibling rivalry. The treatment of choice is bed alarms. Drug of choice is desmopressin. Another medication which can be used is imipramine.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 169.

questions.text: Identify the surgical step shown in the image given below: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capsulorrhexis

 

  • Capsulorrhexis is a step in the conventional extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) method.
  • It is a method of anterior capsulotomy, where an opening is made in the anterior capsule of the lens.
  • Anterior capsulotomy can be done by 3 methods:
    1. Can-opener's technique
    2. Linear capsulotomy or envelope technique
    3. Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis
  • Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis (CCC) is considered superior because it does not leave any edges or tears when done correctly.
  • Trypan blue dye can be used to stain the lens capsule for better visibility during the procedure.
  • In ECCE, a portion of the anterior capsule of the lens is removed, allowing extraction of the lens nucleus and cortex while leaving the remainder of the anterior capsule, the posterior capsule, and the zonular support intact.
  • After capsulorrhexis, hydro dissection is performed using a balanced salt solution to separate the corticonuclear mass from the capsule.
  • Removal of lens nucleus and aspiration of the cortex is done using a two-way irrigation and aspiration cannula.
  • An intraocular lens (IOL) is then implanted, and the incision is closed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydrodissection: Hydrodissection involves injecting fluid under the anterior capsule to separate the lens nucleus from the cortex and the capsule. This procedure follows capsulorrhexis and serves to facilitate the removal of the lens material. The image does not show fluid injection or the separation process typical of hydrodissection.

 

Option C. Intraocular lens implantation: This step involves placing an intraocular lens (IOL) into the capsular bag once the lens material has been removed. In the image, there is no indication of an IOL being handled or inserted, as the focus is solely on manipulating the capsule itself, which precedes the IOL implantation in the surgical sequence.

 

Option D. Lens aspiration: Lens aspiration involves the removal of the lens cortex and nucleus, usually through suction or phacoemulsification, following the capsulorrhexis and hydrodissection steps. The image does not depict any equipment or actions associated with the aspiration of lens material, such as a phacoemulsification handpiece or suction device.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capsulorrhexis is characterized by the creation of a controlled and continuous tear in the anterior capsule of the lens, which is essential for accessing and removing the lens material in cataract surgery. This method provides a clear opening without leaving jagged edges, which is crucial for the structural integrity of the remaining capsule necessary for IOL placement.

questions.text: Congenital lactic acidosis is due to the defect of: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pyruvate dehydrogenase

 

Congenital lactic acidosis occurs when there is an accumulation of lactic acid in the body from birth, often due to a metabolic defect. In normal metabolism, glucose is converted to pyruvate through glycolysis. Under aerobic conditions, pyruvate is transported into the mitochondria, where it is converted into acetyl-CoA by the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase. Acetyl-CoA then enters the Krebs cycle to produce energy in the form of ATP.

 

When there is a deficiency or defect in the pyruvate dehydrogenase enzyme, pyruvate cannot be converted to acetyl-CoA. As a result, pyruvate accumulates and is instead converted to lactate, leading to lactic acidosis. Since this condition is present from birth, it is termed congenital lactic acidosis. Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is one of the key causes of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transketolase: This enzyme plays a role in the pentose phosphate pathway (also known as the hexose monophosphate shunt) and is not directly involved in the conversion of pyruvate or the production of lactic acid. Defects in transketolase do not lead to congenital lactic acidosis.

 

Option B. Branched chain ketoacid dehydrogenase: This enzyme is involved in the metabolism of branched-chain amino acids and its deficiency causes Maple Syrup Urine Disease, not congenital lactic acidosis. It is unrelated to pyruvate metabolism.

 

Option C. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of the Krebs cycle, catalyzing the conversion of isocitrate to alpha-ketoglutarate. While it is involved in cellular respiration, defects in this enzyme are not responsible for congenital lactic acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is a key cause of congenital lactic acidosis, as it prevents the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, leading to an accumulation of lactic acid.

questions.text: Where do afferent fibers from baroreceptors primarily project for blood pressure control? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nucleus Tractus Solitarius

 

Afferent fiber for blood pressure control goes to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS).

 

The afferent fibers from baroreceptors for blood pressure control primarily project to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS). The NTS is located in the medulla oblongata, which is part of the brainstem. It serves as the primary site for integrating and processing information related to blood pressure regulation.

 

The baroreceptors are specialized sensory receptors located in the walls of certain blood vessels, particularly in the carotid sinus and aortic arch. These receptors detect changes in blood pressure and relay this information via afferent (sensory) nerve fibers. The afferent fibers from the baroreceptors transmit signals to the NTS, where they are integrated and contribute to the regulation of blood pressure.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nucleus ambiguous: Incorrect. This nucleus is involved in controlling the muscles of the pharynx, larynx, and soft palate.

 

Option B. Rostral-ventrolateral medulla: Incorrect. This area is involved in the regulation of sympathetic outflow but does not receive direct input from baroreceptor afferents.

 

Option D. Caudal ventrolateral medulla: Incorrect. This area is involved in regulating blood pressure but is not the primary projection site for baroreceptor afferents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Afferent fibers from baroreceptors project to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (NTS) in the medulla oblongata, where they integrate and process information related to blood pressure regulation.

questions.text:
Which of the following instruments are used in the caesarean section?  (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Bard-Parker blade
  2. Doyen's retractor
  3. Cusco's speculum
  4. Allis forceps
  5. Shirodkar's uterine clamp
  6. Green Armytage forceps
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 6

 

Explanation:

 

Instruments used in a cesarean section

 

  • BP handle
  • Allis forceps
  • Artery forceps
  • Doyen retractor
  • Green Armitage forceps
  • Metzenbaum scissors

 

Among the options

 

  • Cusco’s speculum has no role in LSCA It is a vaginal self-retaining speculum with two blades
  • Shirodkar’s uterine clamp is used in gynecological procedures to hold the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify that Bard-Parker blade, Doyen's retractor, Allis forceps, and Green Armytage forceps are essential instruments used in a cesarean section, while Cusco's speculum and Shirodkar's uterine clamp are not used in this procedure.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page no 756

questions.text: A patient presents with uveitis and sacroiliitis. What is most likely associated with it? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HLA B27

 

The presentation of uveitis along with sacroiliitis is a classic manifestation of seronegative spondyloarthropathy, which is strongly associated with HLA-B27. These conditions are characterized by:

 

  • Inflammatory back pain
  • Early morning stiffness lasting more than one hour
  • Pain and stiffness that improve with exercise and worsen with rest
  • Anterior uveitis as the most common extra-articular manifestation
  • Sacroiliitis
  • Peripheral arthritis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HLA B8: Incorrect. Associated with good prognosis in sarcoidosis, not spondyloarthropathy

 

Option C. HLA B5: Incorrect. Associated with Behçet's disease

 

Option D. HLA B51: Incorrect. Also associated with Behçet's disease

 

Educational Objective:

 

HLA-B27 is strongly associated with seronegative spondyloarthropathies, particularly when patients present with the combination of uveitis and sacroiliitis.

questions.text: A confirmed case of which of the following viral hemorrhagic fevers was found in India? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crimean congo hemorrhagic fever

 

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a severe form of viral hemorrhagic fever caused by the Nairovirus species. This disease is zoonotic, meaning it originates from animals, with ticks acting as vectors.

 

Crimean Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF):

 

  • Causative Agent: Nairovirus species.
  • Transmission: The primary vectors are ticks, specifically those of the Hyalomma genus.
  • Outbreaks: The disease can spread through person-to-person transmission, particularly in healthcare settings, where it poses a significant risk to healthcare workers and patients.
  • Symptoms: Include fever, muscle pain, dizziness, neck pain and stiffness, backache, headache, sore eyes, and photophobia. Severe cases can lead to extensive hemorrhaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ebola: Ebola is another severe viral hemorrhagic fever but has not been reported in India. It primarily affects regions in Africa.

 

Option B. Yellow fever: Yellow fever is a mosquito-borne viral hemorrhagic disease endemic to Africa and South America. It has not been reported in India.

 

Option D. Marburg: Marburg virus causes a severe hemorrhagic fever similar to Ebola. It has also not been reported in India and is primarily found in Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is the viral hemorrhagic fever that has been confirmed in India. It is caused by the Nairovirus species and is transmitted by ticks, with potential for person-to-person transmission, especially in healthcare settings.

choices.text: The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.
The left adrenal gland is closely related with the tail of pancreas and spleen.
The adrenal are yellow on gross appearance.
The adrenal are retroperitoneal in location.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the anatomy of the adrenal glands?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.

 

 

  • The right adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape: This statement is false. The right adrenal gland is actually pyramidal in shape. The left adrenal gland is semi-lunar (crescent-shaped) in shape. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The left adrenal gland is closely related with the tail of pancreas and spleen: This statement is true. The left adrenal gland is anatomically positioned near the tail of the pancreas and the spleen.

 

Option C. The adrenal are yellow on gross appearance: This statement is true. The adrenal glands have a yellowish appearance on gross examination due to their rich lipid content.

 

Option D. The adrenal are retroperitoneal in location: This statement is true. The adrenal glands, like the kidneys, are retroperitoneal, meaning they are located behind the peritoneum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The right adrenal gland is pyramidal in shape, while the left adrenal gland is semi-lunar in shape.

questions.text: Which of the following drug should not be prescribed in a patient with G6PD deficiency due to risk of development of hemolysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Primaquine

 

  • G6PD is an enzyme in the hexose monophosphate pathway (HMP) that regulates NADPH levels in the cell. NADPH is required for the conversion of oxidized glutathione to reduced glutathione, which is required to protect the cell from oxidative damage.
  • When drugs like Primaquine are administered in a patient with G6PD deficiency, it causes free radical formation, leading to oxidative stress. This results in intravascular hemolysis.
  • Therefore, Primaquine is contraindicated in G6PD deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chloroquine: Chloroquine is also an antimalarial drug but does not generally cause oxidative stress to the extent that primaquine does. It is less likely to cause hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency.

 

Option C. Penicillin: Penicillin is an antibiotic that is not typically associated with causing oxidative stress or hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency.

 

Option D. Tetracycline: Tetracycline is an antibiotic that is also not associated with causing hemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs contraindicated in G6PD deficiency are –

 

  • Primaquine (Tafenoquine)
  • Dapsone
  • Sulfonamides (including cotrimoxazole)
  • Nitrofurantoin

questions.text:
A patient with cervical lymphadenopathy has (11;14) positive. Which of the following markers should be done to confirm the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. CD10;
  2. CD 200;
  3. SOX11;
  4. Cyclin D1
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3, 4

 

t (11;14) creating CyclinD1-IgH fusion gene is seen in mantle cell lymphoma has its origin from naive B cell.

 

Mantle cell lymphoma:

 

  • Uncommon lymphoid neoplasm that makes up about 8% of all NHL
  • Usually presents in the fifth to sixth decades of life
  • Male predominance
  • Tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells that surround germinal centers
  • More indolent, SOX11 variant that often presents with circulating disease with splenomegaly but without significant lymphadenopathy and with a low Ki67 (<10%).

 

Features:

 

  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • Splenomegaly
  • Multifocal mucosal involvement of small bowel and colon - lymphomatoid polyposis

 

Histology:

 

 

 

Immunophenotyping:

 

  1. High levels of cyclin D1
  2. CD19, CD20
  3. Moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or γ light chain)
  4. CD5+ and CD23-, which helps to distinguish it from CLL/SLL.
  5. The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell.

 

Other Options:

 

  • CD10 (1): CD10 is a marker commonly associated with follicular lymphoma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia, not mantle cell lymphoma.
  • CD200 (2): CD200 is expressed in chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and other B-cell lymphomas but is not a primary marker for mantle cell lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with t(11;14) translocation, confirming the diagnosis of mantle cell lymphoma requires testing for Cyclin D1 and SOX11 expression.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1132-1133

questions.text: A patient following head injury with altered consciousness, vomiting, and GCS of 10/15 undergoes CT scan as shown. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decompression

 

The patient presents with signs of an acute epidural hematoma (EDH), as evidenced by the biconvex (lens-shaped) hyperdense lesion on the CT scan, along with a deteriorating Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10/15. An epidural hematoma is a neurosurgical emergency, especially when accompanied by neuro deterioration, as in this case. The immediate next step is decompression, which involves relieving the pressure on the brain by surgically removing the hematoma. This procedure can be done through a burr hole or craniotomy and is crucial to prevent further brain injury or death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV Mannitol: Although IV mannitol is used to reduce intracranial pressure, it is not the definitive treatment for an acute EDH with neuro deterioration. Mannitol may be used temporarily to manage intracranial pressure, but it does not address the underlying cause of the pressure, which is the hematoma.

 

Option B. Wait and watch: This approach is inappropriate in this scenario due to the immediate threat posed by the hematoma. Delaying treatment could lead to irreversible brain damage or death.

 

Option D. Anticoagulation: Administering anticoagulation would exacerbate the bleeding and worsen the patient’s condition. It is contraindicated in the setting of an active intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidural hematoma with neuro deterioration is a neurosurgical emergency that requires immediate decompression to prevent further brain injury and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text:
Match the following autoimmune diseases with their respective antibodies: (PATHO)

 

Column A:

  1. Systemic Sclerosis
  2. SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
  3. Dermatomyositis
  4. Mixed Connective Tissue Disease

     

Column B:

  1. Anti-U1RNP
  2. Anti-Sm
  3. Anti-topoisomerase
  4. Anti-Jo
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-4, B-2, C-1, D-3

 

  • Systemic Sclerosis: Associated with Anti-topoisomerase antibodies, also known as Anti-Scl-70. These antibodies are specific for systemic sclerosis and are primarily found in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis, indicating a higher risk for severe organ involvement.
  • SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus): Associated with Anti-Sm antibodies. Anti-Sm antibodies are specific markers for SLE and are part of the diagnostic criteria for lupus. They are considered highly specific but not very sensitive.
  • Dermatomyositis: Associated with Anti-Jo antibodies. These antibodies are linked to the inflammatory myopathies, particularly polymyositis and dermatomyositis, and are often associated with interstitial lung disease.
  • Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD): Associated with Anti-U1RNP antibodies. High titers of Anti-U1RNP are characteristic of MCTD, a condition with overlapping features of systemic sclerosis, lupus, and polymyositis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each autoimmune disease has a specific antibody association which aids in diagnosis: Systemic Sclerosis with Anti-topoisomerase, SLE with Anti-Sm, Dermatomyositis with Anti-Jo, and Mixed Connective Tissue Disease with Anti-U1RNP.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding the instrument shown below? (INICET MAY 2018)

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿It is used in women not on thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿It is used in women on thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿It is removed once the patient starts ambulating.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B and C

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image shows a pneumatic compression hose. It is used in women who are not on any thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section.
  • It is also used along with pharmacotherapy in women at risk of thromboembolism undergoing a cesarean section
  • It is discontinued once the patient starts ambulating post-surgery.
  • It is used because pregnancy and surgery increase the risk of thromboembolism.

 

Different guidelines are there for different societies (Both ACOG and SMFM) recommend pneumatic compression devices for all patients undergoing cesarean section. This table is from Williams and shows the different guidelines:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumatic compression devices are used for thromboembolism prevention in women undergoing cesarean sections, whether or not they are on thromboprophylaxis, and are discontinued once the patient starts ambulating post-surgery.

 

Ref: Page 2575, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Tzanck cells
Pund cells

questions.text: A young male presents to the STD clinic with painful lesions as shown in the image. What is the most likely microscopic finding of the lesion? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tzanck cells

 

The clinical picture is suggestive of genital herpes.

 

Tzanck cells – multinucleate giant cells seen on Tzanck smear in herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Herpetic lesions usually begin as clusters of small bumps, then blisters, followed by open sores or ulcers. Lesions coalesce and usually heal over several weeks at various rates. Local pain is a prominent and common complaint. Patients with genital herpes may also complain of pain in the groin area secondary to local adenopathy. Women often present with complaints of genital swelling, discharge, and dysuria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pund cells: Donovan bodies are seen within large, mononuclear (Pund) cells as gram-negative intracytoplasmic cysts filled with deeply staining bodies. Seen in granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) which is a genital ulcerative disease caused by the intracellular gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

 

Donovanosis lesions usually start as a painless papule or subcutaneous nodule. The lesions develop the classic “beefy-red” appearance due to their high vascularity. The initial lesion takes on an ulcerative morphology after minor trauma. There is usually no regional lymphadenopathy. Developing subcutaneous granulomas known as pseudo buboes is possible.

 

 

Option C. Henderson-Patterson bodies: intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies (molluscum bodies, or Henderson-Paterson bodies) are seen in molluscum contagiosum. Lesions are painless, discrete, nontender, flesh-colored, dome-shaped papules (bumps, dimples) that show a central umbilication.

 

 

Option D. Guarnieri bodies: B-type inclusions, formerly known as Guarnieri bodies are cellular features found upon microscopic inspection of epithelial cells of individuals suspected of having poxvirus or vaccinia virus.

 

Educational Objective

 

The presence of Tzanck cells, which are multinucleated giant cells, is indicative of herpes simplex virus infection. This is the most likely microscopic finding in a patient with painful genital lesions consistent with genital herpes.

questions.text: Identify the equipment shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High flow nasal cannula

 

  • Components:
    • Flow generator: This delivers a continuous flow of medical gas, which can be up to 60 liters per minute (L/min) or more in some devices.
    • Heated humidifier: The gas is passed through a humidifier, which warms and saturates the gas with water vapor, providing near 100% humidity. This prevents mucosal drying and enhances mucociliary clearance.
    • Nasal cannula: Despite the term "nasal cannula," the prongs for HFNC are broader and shorter than traditional cannulas. They don't completely occlude the nares, allowing for the patient to breathe room air in addition to the provided gas mixture if needed.

 

Mechanism of Action:

 

  • Gas Conditioning: The humidified and warmed gas ensures better comfort and reduced airway resistance, potentially improving mucociliary function.
  • PEEP Effect: The high flow rates create a degree of positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) in the nasopharynx. This can be beneficial in preventing alveolar collapse and can recruit alveoli, improving oxygenation.
  • Enhanced CO2 Washout: HFNC reduces the anatomical dead space in the nasopharynx, aiding in more efficient removal of carbon dioxide.
  • Continuous High Flow: The high flow rates ensure that the fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) is more consistent, irrespective of the patient's respiratory pattern.

 

Advantages:

 

  • Better oxygenation: By delivering higher flow rates, HFNC can achieve better and more consistent oxygenation compared to standard oxygen therapy.
  • Comfort: Patients often find HFNC more comfortable than non-invasive positive pressure ventilation masks.
  • Flexibility: Patients can eat, drink, and communicate while using HFNC.

 

Indications:

 

  • Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure: Especially if caused by conditions like pneumonia or pulmonary edema.
  • Post-extubation support: In patients at risk for reintubation.
  • During procedures: Like bronchoscopy, to maintain oxygenation.
  • In conditions like COPD and asthma: It may aid in CO2 washout.

 

Limitations and Contraindications:

 

  • Severe hypercapnic respiratory failure: HFNC doesn't provide as much ventilation support as bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP) or mechanical ventilation.
  • Uncooperative or unconscious patients: Due to aspiration risk.
  • Facial trauma or recent facial surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mechanical ventilator: A mechanical ventilator is a device used to support or replace spontaneous breathing. It is more complex and provides controlled ventilation through an endotracheal tube or tracheostomy.

 

Option B. Infusion pump: An infusion pump delivers fluids, such as nutrients and medications, into a patient's body in controlled amounts. It is not related to respiratory support.

 

Option C. CPAP machine: A Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) machine delivers a continuous level of positive airway pressure to keep the airways open. It is commonly used in sleep apnea but does not provide the high flow rates and humidification characteristic of HFNC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High flow nasal cannula (HFNC) is a respiratory support system that delivers high flow rates of humidified and warmed oxygen, providing benefits such as improved oxygenation, patient comfort, and flexibility in use.

questions.text:
What are the components of Nada's Minor Criteria? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Systolic mumur Grade 3
  2. Diastolic murmur
  3. Abnormal second heart sound
  4. Abnormal BP
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 and 4

 

Nada’s criteria is used for detection of CHD on the basis of clinical evaluation.

 

 

Presence of 1 major or 2 minor criteria suggest presence of heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In Nada’s criteria for detecting congenital heart disease, minor criteria include an abnormal second heart sound and abnormal blood pressure. The presence of one major or two minor criteria suggests the presence of heart disease.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes with a history of postcoital bleeding and a visible mass seen in cervix per speculum. The next step to be done? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Targeted biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

A targeted biopsy (punch biopsy) is the next line of management in the above case as the patient is symptomatic (postcoital bleeding) and has a visible lesion. The biopsy will help in diagnosing the nature of the lesion, which is crucial for further management.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Conization: Conization is an excisional procedure done once biopsy-proven intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN 2 and 3) is diagnosed. It is not the initial step when a visible lesion is present and needs to be assessed.

 

Option B. Cryotherapy: Cryotherapy is an ablative procedure done for CIN 1 or 2. It is not suitable for a visible lesion with postcoital bleeding without a prior biopsy.

 

Option D. Pap smear: Pap smear is done when there are symptoms with no identifiable lesion. In the presence of a visible mass, a direct biopsy is more appropriate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a symptomatic patient with postcoital bleeding and a visible lesion on the cervix, the next step is a targeted biopsy to diagnose the nature of the lesion.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg662, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg345

questions.text: Decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle occurs at which level?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Midbrain

 

Explanation:

 

The decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle occurs in the midbrain, at the level of the inferior colliculus.

 

The midbrain has four decussations:

 

  • At the level of the superior colliculus:
    • Ventral tegmental decussation of the rubrospinal tract
    • Dorsal tegmental decussation of the tectospinal tract

 

 

  • At the level of the inferior colliculus:
    • Decussation of superior cerebellar peduncles
    • Decussation of trochlear nerve

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pons: The pons is a part of the brainstem located above the medulla and below the midbrain. It contains nuclei that deal with sleep, respiration, bladder control, hearing, taste, eye movement, facial expressions, facial sensation, and posture. While the pons does have connections with the cerebellum (mainly through the middle cerebellar peduncle), the decussation of the superior cerebellar peduncle doesn't happen here.

 

Option C. Diencephalon: The diencephalon is a region of the forebrain that includes the thalamus, hypothalamus, and epithalamus. While the superior cerebellar peduncle does send fibers to the thalamus, the decussation doesn't happen in the diencephalon.

 

Option D. Medulla: The medulla oblongata, commonly referred to simply as the medulla, is the lower part of the brainstem. It's continuous with the spinal cord and contains many important neural pathways and centers for autonomic functions. The medulla does contain decussations, but they are mainly associated with the pyramidal tracts (motor pathways) and not with the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The midbrain, or mesencephalon, is the uppermost part of the brainstem, lying between the pons and the diencephalon. The superior cerebellar peduncle fibers decussate (cross) in the midbrain to reach the contralateral red nucleus and thalamus. This is why lesions in the cerebellum typically affect the same side of the body: the fibers effectively "double-cross," first decussating in the midbrain and then crossing again at higher levels in the brain.

choices.text: Acute kidney injury (AKI)
Chronic renal failure

questions.text: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used to classify? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)

 

The AKIN (Acute Kidney Injury Network) and RIFLE (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss of kidney function, and End-stage kidney disease) criteria are specifically designed to classify and diagnose Acute Kidney Injury (AKI). These criteria help in early detection and grading the severity of AKI based on changes in serum creatinine, urine output, and duration of symptoms.

 

Current diagnosis is based on the KDIGO group criteria. Urine output (OR) Creatinine rise is considered in the diagnosis.

 

KDIGO group criteria for diagnosis of AKI:

 

  1. Increase in S. Creatinine ≥ 0.3mg/dL.
  2. Increase in S. Creatinine ≥ 1.5 times of baseline that is known/presumed to have occur in the past 7 days.
  3. Urine volume < 0.5ml/kg/hour for 6 hours.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute glomerulonephritis: This has specific clinical and laboratory features distinct from AKI.

 

Option C. Chronic renal failure: Characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over months to years.

 

Option D. Nephrotic syndrome: Defined by high levels of protein in the urine, low levels of protein in the blood, high levels of cholesterol, and swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AKIN and RIFLE criteria are essential tools for diagnosing and assessing the severity of Acute Kidney Injury, which can guide interventions and predict outcomes in affected patients. They emphasize changes in serum creatinine and urine output as key indicators of kidney function.

questions.text: Which of the following sensory receptors are responsible for tactile discrimination? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Meissner's corpuscle

 

Meissner's Corpuscles are responsible for discriminative touch.

 

 

 

Meissner’s corpuscle

 

Touch receptor with great sensitivity

An elongated encapsulated nerve ending of a large (type AB. myelinated sensory nerve fiber. Inside the capsulation are many branching terminal nerve filaments.

 

Present in the non-hairy parts of the skin and are particularly abundant in the fingertips, lips, and other areas of the skin where one’s ability to discern spatial locations of touch sensations is highly developed.

 

These are responsible for-Two Point discrimination, Fine touch and Slow vibration

 

If the question asks - Best for 2 point discrimination/ best for Braille reading/ static 2 point discrimination - the answer is Merkel


If the question asks - Most common/ most abundant/ maximum on glabrous skin/ primary / dynamic 2 point discrimination - the answer is Meissners
 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Merkel Disc: Allows one to determine continuous touch of objects against the skin.

 

Option B. Ruffini End Organ: Responsible for temperature sensation.

 

Option C. Pacinian Corpuscle: Responsible for pressure and crude touch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meissner's corpuscles are specialized for discriminative touch, enabling precise location and detection of fine tactile stimuli. They are most abundant in areas where tactile acuity is high, such as the fingertips and lips

questions.text: Which of the following types of amino acids are present in the trans-membranous part of the membrane receptor? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrophobic

 

Integral or transmembrane proteins are the proteins that pass through entire thickness of cell membrane from one side to the other side. These proteins are tightly bound with the cell membrane.

 

The trans membranous part of the membrane receptor consists of hydrophobic amino acids.

 

The central core of the cell membrane is hydrophobic.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amphipathic: Incorrect. Amphipathic molecules contain both hydrophobic and hydrophilic regions, but the transmembrane segments of proteins are primarily hydrophobic.

 

Option C. Hydrophilic: Incorrect. Hydrophilic amino acids have polar side chains that would not favorably interact with the hydrophobic core of the lipid bilayer.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect. Hydrophobic amino acids are indeed present in the transmembranous part of the membrane receptor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The transmembrane regions of membrane receptors are composed of hydrophobic amino acids, allowing them to stably integrate into the hydrophobic core of the lipid bilayer.

 

Examples of integral protein:

 

  1. Cell adhesion proteins
  2. Cell junction proteins
  3. Some carrier (transport) proteins
  4. Channel proteins
  5. Some hormone receptors
  6. Antigens
  7. Some enzymes.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is not involved in taste sensation?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hypoglossal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The hypoglossal nerve is purely motor cranial nerve and is not involved in taste sensation.

 

All intrinsic and the majority of the extrinsic muscles of the tongue are innervated by General Somatic Efferent fibres, which are motor fibres that supply skeletal muscles. It emerges as many rootlets from the medulla's front surface, travels laterally across the posterior cerebral fossa, and then leaves through the hypoglossal canal. All intrinsic tongue muscles, including the hyoglossus, styloglossus, and genioglossus muscles, are innervated by this nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trigeminal nerve (CN V): The trigeminal nerve a mixed cranial nerve primarily responsible for sensations in the face, including touch, temperature, and pain. While it is not directly involved in olfaction (smell), it can indirectly influence the perception of smell. Irritants or substances that produce strong odors can activate the trigeminal nerve's pain and temperature receptors in the nasal passages, leading to sensations like "spiciness" or irritation when inhaling certain substances.

 

Option B. Vagus nerve (CN X): The vagus nerve is not directly involved in olfaction. It primarily serves functions related to the autonomic nervous system, including controlling various organs and muscles in the thoracic and abdominal regions. It does not have a direct role in the sense of smell but Vagal nerve stimulation modifies the electrical activity of the olfactory bulb.

 

Option C. Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX): The glossopharyngeal nerve is also a mixed cranial nerve and not directly involved in olfaction. It has various functions, including the transmission of sensory information from the back of the throat and parts of the tongue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) is primarily responsible for the motor control of the muscles of the tongue. It does not have any direct involvement in olfaction or the sense of smell.

questions.text: In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), which of the following findings would be atypical for a classification of 'very severe’? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neovascularization of disc

 

  • In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), it is important to understand the typical and atypical findings associated with the disease severity:

 

This is considered an atypical finding for NPDR and is generally associated with proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). NVD indicates a more severe and advanced stage where new blood vessels grow on the optic disc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous Bleeding: In NPDR, more common findings are microaneurysms or dot hemorrhages.

 

Option C. Retinal Hemorrhages: Common in NPDR, especially as the severity increases. These hemorrhages are often small and scattered throughout the retina.

 

Option D. Microaneurysm: A hallmark and typically one of the earliest signs of NPDR. These are small, round, red spots seen on fundoscopic examination caused by capillary dilatation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When examining a patient with diabetic retinopathy, finding neovascularization would necessitate reclassification to proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which requires different management strategies including possible laser therapy or anti-VEGF injections to prevent further vision loss.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child with ambiguous genitalia presented to the hospital, his BP is 88/68 mm Hg, Serum K+ is 6 mEq/L, serum sodium is 120 mEq/L. Patient was started on intravenous fluids. What additional specific therapy will you add?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hydrocortisone

 

The presentation of an 18-month-old child with ambiguous genitalia, hypertension (BP is 88/68 mm Hg, which is low for this age), hyperkalemia (serum K of 6 mEq/L), and hyponatremia (serum sodium of 120 mEq/L) is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), most likely due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This is a common form of CAH and can lead to a decrease in cortisol and aldosterone production, with an accompanying increase in adrenal androgens.

 

Given this clinical picture, the specific therapy to be added would include:
