  1. Glucocorticoid Replacement: This is critical to suppress the overproduction of adrenal androgens. Hydrocortisone is commonly used, especially in pediatric patients, due to its short duration of action and lower impact on growth.

  2. Mineralocorticoid Replacement: Fludrocortisone is usually added to manage the aldosterone deficiency, which is contributing to the hyperkalemia and hyponatremia.

  3. Sodium Chloride Supplements: In some cases, especially in infants and young children, additional sodium chloride supplements may be necessary to manage hyponatremia.

  4. Monitoring and Adjustment: Regular monitoring of electrolytes, blood pressure, and growth is necessary to adjust therapy accordingly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Potassium Binding Resins: While these can be used to treat hyperkalemia, they do not address the underlying cause of the electrolyte imbalance in this scenario, which is likely due to aldosterone deficiency. Therefore, it would not be the first choice.

 

Option C. Digoxin: This is used primarily for heart failure and certain arrhythmias, not for the conditions described in this scenario.

 

Option D. Calcium Gluconate: This is used in the acute management of severe hyperkalemia to stabilize cardiac membranes. While it might be used in an emergency setting for life-threatening hyperkalemia, it does not address the underlying cause in this case and is not a long-term management strategy.

 

Therefore, the most appropriate addition to this patient's treatment regimen would be Hydrocortisone (option a), as it addresses the underlying cause of the symptoms in CAH. Additionally, monitoring and adjusting mineralocorticoid therapy (like fludrocortisone) would be important in the long-term management, especially given the electrolyte imbalances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate addition to this patient's treatment regimen would be Hydrocortisone, as it addresses the underlying cause of the symptoms in CAH. Additionally, monitoring and adjusting mineralocorticoid therapy (like fludrocortisone) would be important in the long-term management, especially given the electrolyte imbalances.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/314

questions.text: A diagram illustrating the natural history of a disease has points marked A, B, C, and D. Which point indicates the onset of symptoms in the disease's natural history? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Point C

 

Point C: Marks onset of clinical signs and symptoms

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Point A: Entry of infectious agent into the host.

 

Option B. Point B: Pathological and physiological changes occur in the stage of the subclinical phase. These changes are induced by the causative agent but are not sufficient enough to cause clinical signs and symptoms.

 

Option D. Point D: Usual time of diagnosis at which clinical signs and symptoms are well evident.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopy depiction of a cellular structure. Determine the type of cell being depicted: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

 

Hairy cells are seen in Hairy cell leukemia. It is a B-cell tumor. Peripheral smear shows pancytopenia; hairy cells. Flow cytometry shows CD11/25/103 + cells. Annexin –A is the best marker.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Target cell: Target cell can be seen in thalassemia, hepatic disease with jaundice, hemoglobin C disorders, and the postsplenectomy state.

 

 

Option C. Gaucher cell: Gaucher cell is found in Gaucher’s disease which occurs due to absence of beta glucocerebrosidase enzyme..

 

 

Option D. Sickle cells: Sickle cells are seen in sickle cell anemia. HbS has altered solubility and high chance of polymer formation especially with dehydration or hypoxemia causing alteration in shape. On rehydration, it is reversible.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hairy cells, with their distinctive cytoplasmic projections, are a hallmark of Hairy Cell Leukemia, a chronic B-cell malignancy.

questions.text: What does the Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW) measure?  (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anisocytosis

 

Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW) is a measure of the variation in red blood cell (RBC) size. Anisocytosis, which is the variation in the sizes of RBCs, is directly assessed by RDW. A higher RDW indicates a greater variation in size. RDW is used clinically to help differentiate between types of anemia and to provide insight into the underlying mechanisms of anemia. Normal RDW values range from 11-14%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypochromia: Refers to RBCs having less color than normal, indicative of less hemoglobin content per cell, not directly related to RDW.

 

Option C. Poikilocytosis: Indicates variation in the shape of RBCs, not their size, hence not directly assessed by RDW.

 

Option D. Anisochromia: Refers to variation in hemoglobin content among RBCs, which is not measured by RDW.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RDW measures the variability in size of red blood cells, which is indicative of anisocytosis. High RDW is associated with conditions like iron deficiency anemia and other types of anemia, where there is significant variation in RBC sizes.

 

Additional Information

 

IDA vs Thalassemia

 

IDA- rbcs are small (low MCV ) with high RDW

 

Thalassemia- RBCs are small (low MCV )  with normal RDW

questions.text: Which of the following will not be avid on FDG PET scan? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Typical carcinoid

 

Explanation:

 

Typical carcinoids generally do not show avid uptake on an FDG PET scan because they are well-differentiated tumors with relatively low metabolic activity compared to more aggressive cancers. FDG PET scans are most effective in identifying tumors that have high glucose metabolism, which is more characteristic of rapidly growing and less differentiated tumors. Typical carcinoids, being slow-growing, often exhibit minimal FDG uptake, making them less detectable on PET scans.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Small cell carcinoma: This type of cancer is highly aggressive and shows high metabolic activity, making it usually very avid on FDG PET scans.

 

Option C. Atypical carcinoid: More aggressive than typical carcinoids, often showing intermediate to high FDG uptake due to higher metabolic activity.

 

Option D. Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma: A highly aggressive neuroendocrine tumor that generally shows significant FDG uptake due to its rapid growth and high metabolic rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumors false-negative on PET-CT:

 

Lung adenocarcinoma

Mucinous adenocarcinoma

Typical carcinoid

questions.text:
A patient presents with severe vomiting and diarrhea and has orthostatic hypotension. What metabolic abnormalities would you expect in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1.Hypokalemia

2.Hypochloremia

3.Metabolic alkalosis

4.Respiratory alkalosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea can lead to multiple metabolic abnormalities: Hypokalemia, Hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

 

1. Hypokalemia: Loss of potassium through vomiting and diarrhea.

 

2. Hypochloremia: Loss of chloride.

 

3. Metabolic alkalosis: Loss of gastric acids.

 

These changes are due to the loss of electrolytes and fluids.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Respiratory alkalosis involves hyperventilation and a decrease in carbon dioxide, which is unrelated to the described condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea typically cause hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man was brought to the hospital with complaints of dizziness and breathlessness. During his physical examination, you notice the following discoloration over his face. He is presently being treated with amiodarone, metoprolol, verapamil, lisinopril, and amlodipine. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amiodarone

 

Amiodarone is known to cause skin discoloration, which can appear as a bluish or greyish hue, especially on areas exposed to the sun. This effect is due to the drug's deposition in the skin and can occur after prolonged use. Amiodarone-induced skin discoloration (also known as ceruloderma or blue man syndrome) is the most likely cause of the bluish discoloration in this patient's case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amlodipine: A calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension and angina. Skin discoloration is not a common side effect of amlodipine.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: A beta-blocker used for various heart conditions, including hypertension and arrhythmias. Metoprolol is not typically associated with skin discoloration.

 

Option D. Verapamil: Another calcium channel blocker used for hypertension, angina, and certain arrhythmias. Like amlodipine, it is not commonly associated with causing skin discoloration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone can cause a characteristic bluish or greyish discoloration of the skin, particularly in sun-exposed areas, due to its deposition in the skin after prolonged use. This side effect is not commonly associated with the other medications listed (amlodipine, metoprolol, and verapamil).

choices.text: Only the roots of this plant are poisonous
Drug of choice for poisoning is Atropine
Mitha zeher is one of the varieties of this plant

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the picture given below? (AIIMS May 2018,)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Only the roots of this plant are poisonous

 

The image shows aconite, a highly toxic plant. All parts of the aconite plant are poisonous, not just the roots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Causes AV block: Correct statement. Aconite poisoning causes AV block due to its effects on the heart.

 

Option C. Drug of choice for poisoning is Atropine: Correct statement. Atropine is used to counteract the bradycardia and AV block caused by aconite poisoning.

 

Option D. Mitha zeher is one of the varieties of this plant: Correct statement. "Mitha zeher" is a common name for aconite.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aconite:

 

  • All parts of the plant are poisonous.
  • Aconite is also called as - monkhood, mitha zeher, bish, and bikh.
  • Method of poisoning - It is a cardiac poison and causes AV block, bradycardia.
  • Treatment of choice - Atropine

questions.text: A child presented with complaints of itching and discharges on flexure aspect of elbow and the lesions were red as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atopic dermatitis

 

The most likely diagnosis for the case presented is atopic dermatitis, a common inflammatory skin condition often associated with the atopic state, which includes eczema, asthma, and allergic rhinitis. This condition is characterized by impaired epidermal barrier function, often due to a genetic predisposition. In many patients, a mutation in the filaggrin gene is responsible for this barrier defect.

 

Atopic dermatitis typically presents with:

 

  • Eczematous lesions: These lesions are often red, inflamed, and may ooze or become crusted. They frequently occur in flexural areas such as the elbows, knees, and neck.
  • Pruritus (itching): Intense itching is a hallmark of atopic dermatitis, often leading to scratching that can exacerbate the lesions.
  • Chronic course: The condition usually has a chronic course with periods of exacerbation and remission. Lesions often persist for more than 6 weeks.
  • Family history: There is often a personal or family history of atopic conditions, including asthma, allergic rhinitis, or food allergies.
  • Lichenification: Chronic scratching may lead to thickened, leathery skin, known as lichenification.

 

The clinical image provided shows red, excoriated lesions in the flexure aspect of the elbow, which is highly characteristic of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus vulgaris: This is an autoimmune blistering disorder that typically presents with flaccid blisters and erosions on the skin and mucous membranes, not with the eczematous lesions seen in atopic dermatitis.

 

Option B. Psoriasis: Psoriasis typically presents with well-demarcated, thick, silvery scales on extensor surfaces like the elbows and knees. It is not associated with the flexural distribution or the intense pruritus seen in atopic dermatitis.

 

Option C. Post-traumatic pigmentation: This refers to skin discoloration following an injury. It does not present with eczematous lesions or intense itching, and it is not limited to flexural areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atopic dermatitis typically presents with pruritic, eczematous lesions on flexural areas, often associated with a personal or family history of atopy.

questions.text: Identify the type of joint marked in the image: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Saddle

 

  • The marked joint in the image is the incudo-malleolar joint, which is a type of saddle joint. This joint is located in the middle ear and involves the malleus and incus bones. The mnemonic "SBI" helps remember the types of joints in relation to the incus:
    • S for Saddle joint (incudo-malleolar joint)
    • B for Ball and socket joint (incudo-stapedial joint)
    • I for the Incus, positioned in front and behind the respective joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ball and socket: Incorrect. The ball and socket joint is found in the incudo-stapedial joint, not the incudo-malleolar joint.

 

Option C. Plane: Incorrect. The plane joint is not represented in the middle ear ossicles.

 

Option D. Gliding: Incorrect. Gliding joints are not present in the middle ear ossicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The incudo-malleolar joint is a saddle joint, an important anatomical feature in the middle ear.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with cervical lymphadenopathy. As a part of the evaluation, the Paul-Bunnell test was done. What is the principle of this test? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterophile antibodies

 

The principle of the Paul-Bunnell test is based on heterophile antibodies.

 

Heterophile antibodies agglutinate shared antigens.

 

Paul-Bunnell test is used diagnosing for infectious mononucleosis, wherein heterophile antibodies agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.

 

The Weil-Felix reaction is another example heterophile agglutination test. Here the common antigen is shared between typhus rickettsia and some strains of proteus bacilli. It is helpful in the serodiagnosis of typhus fevers.

 

Streptococcus MG agglutination test for primary atypical pneumonia and the cold agglutination test for mycoplasma (primary atypical) pneumonia are also based on heterophile antibody.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complement fixation: Incorrect: The complement fixation test is based on the ability of antigen-antibody complexes to fix complement. This is a different mechanism from the heterophile antibody agglutination used in the Paul-Bunnell test.

 

Option B. Super-antigens: Incorrect: Superantigens are a class of antigens that cause excessive activation of the immune system by non-specific activation of T-cells, leading to massive cytokine release. This is not related to the Paul-Bunnell test.

 

Option D. Haptens: Incorrect: Haptens are small molecules that elicit an immune response only when attached to a large carrier such as a protein. The Paul-Bunnell test does not involve haptens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Paul-Bunnell test is based on the detection of heterophile antibodies, which agglutinate sheep erythrocytes, and is used in the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: Entry of glucose is insulin independent in all of them except: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Adipose tissues

 

Glucose enters cells through GLUT (glucose transporter) proteins. Some are insulin-dependent, while others are not.

 

Adipose tissues:
•    Use GLUT4
•    Insulin-dependent
•    Insulin stimulates translocation of GLUT4 to membrane → increases glucose uptake

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. RBC (Red Blood Cells)
•    Use GLUT1
•    Insulin-independent

 

Option B. Pancreas (β-cells)
•    Use GLUT2
•    Insulin-independent
•    Glucose entry triggers insulin secretion

 

Option D. Brain
•    Uses GLUT1 (BBB) and GLUT3 (neurons)
•    Both are insulin-independent
•    Brain requires a constant glucose supply regardless of insulin


 

Educational Objective:

 

Major Glucose transporters and their function is summarized as:

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

1. Delirium Tremens (A-3): Benzodiazepines like oxazepam are the first-line treatment for delirium tremens, along with thiamine supplementation. 

 

2. Opioid Overdose (B-4): Naloxone is the specific antidote for opioid overdose. It acts as an opioid antagonist and can rapidly reverse respiratory depression caused by opioids.

 

3. Alcohol Dependence (C-2): Acamprosate is used in alcohol dependence to maintain abstinence by modulating glutamatergic neurotransmission. It reduces craving for alcohol.

 

4. Smoking Cessation (D-1): Varenicline is the most effective medication for smoking cessation. It reduces cravings and withdrawal symptoms by acting as a partial agonist at nicotinic receptors

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What are the tactile hallucinations observed in instances of prolonged cocaine intoxication? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formication

 

Formication, characterized by the feeling of insects moving beneath the skin, is a notable occurrence in cases of cocaine abuse. This phenomenon is also commonly denoted as Magnan's syndrome or cocaine bugs.

 

COCAINE

 

  • Derived from the plant, Erythroxylum coca
  • Sigmund Freud studied its pharmacological effects and probably had an addiction to cocaine too.
  • Was initially used as a local anaesthetic (as it blocks fast sodium channels), especially for ENT surgeries.
  • Blocks dopamine and norepinephrine receptors (dopamine & NE reuptake is inhibited) resulting in-
    • Vasoconstriction: HTN, MI
    • Nasal septal perforation (nasal inhalation of cocaine results in nasal congestion and long-term use can cause nasal septal perforation)
    • Seizures
    • Jet black pigmentation of tongue
  • Routes of administration - Snorting (inhalation of finely powdered form into the nose), freebasing (smoking), I.V. and subcutaneous.

 

Intoxication

 

  • Euphoria
  • Sympathetic symptoms (tachycardia, palpitations, hypertension, sweating, mydriasis)
  • Paranoid ideations (persecutory ideations) + auditory hallucinations
  • Tactile hallucinations or cocaine bugs or magnan phenomenon or formication (sensation of insects crawling under the skin)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oneroid state is a dream-like fantastic delusional derangement of consciousness

 

Option C. Dipsomania is a historical term describing a medical condition involving an uncontrollable craving for alcohol or drugs.

 

Option D. Carphologia is a lint-picking behavior that is often a symptom of a delirious state.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided head tilt which on straightening leads to right hypotropia increases on dextroversion and right head tilt. Paralysis of which of the following muscles is involved? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right superior rectus

 

  • The clinical scenario described is due to right superior rectus palsy.
  • The three-step test, also called the Parks-Bielschowsky three-step test, can help diagnose which muscle is paralyzed in acquired hypertropia. It involves using the cover-uncover test and Maddox rod to measure deviation in different head positions.
  • The three-step test can also diagnose inferior oblique or vertical rectus muscle palsy, but it's not reliable for multiple paretic muscles or restrictive strabismus.
  • In patients with inhibitional palsy of the contralateral antagonist, the three-step test can distinguish between true or simulated superior rectus palsy.

 

Using the three-step test in the above clinical scenario:

 

Step 1. Which eye is hypotropic?

 

The eye hypotropic in the primary position is the right eye. The paretic muscles can be right eye elevator or left eye depressor.

 

  • Right superior rectus
  • Right inferior oblique
  • Left inferior rectus
  • Left superior oblique

 

Step 2. Does the hypotropia increase in the right gaze or left gaze?

 

The hypotropia increases in right gaze.

 

Therefore, the paretic muscle must be either (1) one of the muscles whose primary action is elevating the right eye on the right gaze, or (2) one of the muscles whose primary action is depressing the left eye in the right gaze. The left inferior oblique and the right superior rectus both have a primary action of elevation in right gaze. Therefore, one of these muscles could be the paretic muscle. Likewise, the left superior oblique and the right inferior rectus have a primary action of depression in the right gaze and could be paretic. But since the left inferior oblique and the right inferior rectus did not meet step 1, they can be eliminated from the possible paretic muscles. This leaves us:

 

  • Left superior oblique
  • Right superior rectus

 

Step 3. Does the hypotropia increase in the right head tilt or left head tilt?

 

The hypotropia increases in the right head tilt. If the deviation increases on right head tilt and decreases on left head tilt, as it does in this example patient, then the right superior rectus is implicated as the paretic culprit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right superior oblique: Incorrect, as paralysis typically leads to hypertropia and excyclotorsion, not hypotropia.

 

Option C. Right inferior oblique: Incorrect, as paralysis would not result in the described pattern of hypotropia.

 

Option D. Left inferior oblique: Incorrect, since paralysis here does not explain the increase in hypotropia with right head tilt and right gaze.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three-step test is a vital diagnostic tool in strabismus evaluations to identify which extraocular muscle is paretic based on the changes in eye position with head tilt and gaze direction. In this scenario, the findings align with a right superior rectus muscle palsy, consistent with its role in elevating the right eye especially during right gaze and head tilt to the right.

questions.text: During total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, which of the following steps will not lead to hoarseness of voice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dissection of strap muscles

 

Hoarseness of voice after thyroidectomy is generally due to injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), which controls the vocal cords. The RLN is located near the thyroid gland, and careful surgical technique is necessary to avoid damaging it. The strap muscles, which are located anterior to the thyroid gland, are far from the path of the RLN, so dissecting these muscles will not result in hoarseness of voice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option  A. Dissection of Beahr’s triangle: The recurrent laryngeal nerve forms the anterior boundary of Beahr’s triangle, making it susceptible to injury during dissection, which can lead to hoarseness.

 

Option B. Dissection of Zuckerkandl tubercle: The Zuckerkandl tubercle is closely associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve, so dissection in this area can risk nerve injury and subsequent hoarseness.

 

Option D. Ligation of Superior thyroid artery: This procedure is generally more likely to affect the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve rather than the recurrent laryngeal nerve, but in cases of anatomical variation, there is a small risk that the RLN could be affected, potentially leading to hoarseness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dissection of the strap muscles during thyroidectomy does not involve the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and therefore, will not cause hoarseness of voice.

questions.text: A Himachal gardener man walks barefoot. Which infection is he prone to develop? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Madurella Mycetomatis

 

Madurella mycetomatis causes mycetoma (madura foot), a chronic granulomatous infection that typically occurs through direct inoculation via barefoot walking. 
The condition presents with the classic triad (GST):

 

  • Grains/Granules:  Coming out through sinus tracts
  • Sinuses:  Multiple draining sinuses
  • Tumefaction:  Swelling of the affected area.

 

Mycetoma can be:

 

Eumycetoma: Caused by fungi like Madurella mycetomatis

 

Actinomycetoma: Caused by bacteria.

 

Treatment includes antifungals for eumycetoma and the modified Welsh regimen (Cotrimoxazole, Amikacin, Rifampicin) for Actinomycetoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cryptococcosis: It's primarily acquired through inhalation of Cryptococcus neoformns and typically causes pulmonary or CNS infection, not through barefoot walking.

 

Option C. Toxocara canis: Helminthic infection is acquired through ingestion of contaminated soil or feces, not through barefoot walking.

 

Option D. Coccidioides immitis: It causes coccidioidomycosis through inhalation of fungal spores, primarily affecting the respiratory system, not through barefoot walking.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barefoot walking predisposes to mycetoma caused by Madurella mycetomatis, presenting with the classic triad of grains, sinuses, and tumefaction.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient has NYHA class III heart failure, with dyspnea, pedal edema and K+ levels of 5.5mg% and creatinine 1.1 mg%. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Furosemide

 

Furosemide can be used in this patient. All the other drugs mentioned are avoided due to the risk of hyperkalemia.

 

Beta – blockers- interferes with beta 2 mediated intracellular potassium uptake.

 

ACE Inhibitors- inhibition of angiotensin II formation with a decrease in aldosterone secretion.

 

Angiotensin II receptors blockers (ARBS)- block AT1 receptor, decreasing in aldosterone.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: Typically avoided if there's a risk of hyperkalemia, as it can be dangerous in elevated potassium levels, potentially causing cardiac arrhythmias.

 

Option B. Spironolactone: Being a potassium-sparing diuretic, it is contraindicated in patients with high serum potassium levels as it could exacerbate hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Enalapril: As an ACE inhibitor, it can increase potassium levels by reducing aldosterone secretion, thus inappropriate for patients already presenting with hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In heart failure patients with elevated potassium levels, loop diuretics like furosemide are preferred to manage fluid overload and avoid exacerbation of hyperkalemia, unlike potassium-sparing diuretics or ACE inhibitors.

choices.text: Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true
Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true
Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false
Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing the results of a study comparing two antihypertensive drugs in an Indian population. She comes across the term "p-value" in her statistical analyses. Which of the following best describes the interpretation of a p-value with regard to the probability related to the null hypothesis? [AIIMS NOV 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true

 

  • The p-value represents the likelihood of mistakenly rejecting a true null hypothesis. It serves as the threshold for determining statistical significance.
  • In essence, the p-value signifies the probability of erroneously rejecting a valid null hypothesis, leading to a Type I error.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is true: This describes a correct decision where the null hypothesis is true, and the researcher correctly decides not to reject it. This scenario does not involve a p-value interpretation.

 

Option C. Not rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false: This describes a Type II error, where the null hypothesis is false, but the researcher fails to reject it. The p-value is not directly related to this scenario.

 

Option D. Rejecting a null hypothesis when it is false: This describes a correct decision where the null hypothesis is false, and the researcher correctly rejects it. This is the goal of hypothesis testing but not the specific interpretation of a p-value.

 

Null Hypothesis

 

  • Hypothesis (H): Is an assumption about the status of a phenomenon
  • Null Hypothesis (H0): In Biostatistics, when we have to prove a particular hypothesis about difference between 2 regimens, we make Null Hypothesis (For examples, If we have to prove that new treatment is better than older treatment, H0 = new treatment is not better than older treatment).

choices.text: Fanconi anemia

questions.text: Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in which of the following diseases other than nephrotic syndrome? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fabry's disease

 

Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in Fabry's disease.

 

Maltese cross birefringence is caused by a radially birefringent substance such as a lipid droplet.

 

 

Fabry disease is a genetic disorder caused by deficiency of lysosomal alpha-galactosidase A leading to accumulation of metabolic intermediates like glycosphingolipids etc.

 

Urine analysis in Fabry's disease shows oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarized light showing a Maltese cross appearance. It can also be seen in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Friedrich's ataxia: This is a genetic disorder that affects the nervous system and does not involve the formation of Maltese cross crystals in the urine.

 

Option B. Felty syndrome: This syndrome is a complication of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis, characterized by splenomegaly and neutropenia. It does not cause the formation of Maltese cross crystals in the urine.

 

Option C. Fanconi anemia: A genetic disorder that primarily affects the bone marrow, leading to aplastic anemia and increased cancer risk, but it is not associated with the presence of Maltese cross crystals in the urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in Fabry's disease, indicating the presence of lipid-laden cells.

questions.text: Which among the following has the highest airway resistance? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchi

 

Among the given options, bronchi (medium-sized airway) offer maximum resistance.

 

The best answer here is bronchi, as the other options suggest smaller airways and bronchi is the only medium-sized airway.

 

Since the airway branches in each generation exist in parallel rather than in series, smallest airway contributes little to overall resistance. As the parallel branching increases, the resistance decreases because the total cross-sectional diameter of small airways put together is high resulting in less resistance. Also, airflow velocity decreases substantially because the effective cross-sectional area increases (i.e., the flow becomes laminar).

 

Other factors affecting airway resistance:

 

  • Lung volume, as lung volume increases the resistance decreases and vice versa. Lung volume increases the trans airway pressure thus increasing the caliber of the airway.
  • Airway mucus, edema, and contraction of bronchial smooth muscle increase the airway resistance. Its clinical application is seen in asthma, bronchitis, and emphysema
  • The density and viscosity of inspired gas also contribute to airway resistance. A gas with more density imparts more resistance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveolar duct and C. Respiratory bronchioles: These smaller airways have much lower resistance due to their large total cross-sectional area, which reduces resistance despite their small individual diameters.

 

Option D. Small bronchioles: Similar to the respiratory bronchioles, their high number and extensive branching reduce overall resistance.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bronchi, the medium-sized airways, have the highest airway resistance due to their relatively narrow diameter compared to the total cross-sectional area of smaller airways.

 

Airflow can be derived from Poiseuille- Hagen formula:

 

 

Where:

 

  • R is the resistance
  • is pie symbol
  • r is radius
  • is viscosity
  • L is length

 

According to Poisuille’s formula, Airway resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power radius.

 

Poiseuille- Hagen formula suggests that the smallest airways are the major site of resistance.

questions.text: What is the first step in the management of an 18-month-old child with both eyes deviated medially? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Refractive error testing

 

In children, who present with a convergent squint, the first step is to check the visual acuity and estimate the error of refraction.

 

  • When the child presents, the distant vision is recorded and atropine 1% eye ointment, 3 times a day, is prescribed for three days.
  • After 3 days, the error of refraction is estimated by retinoscopy.
  • Fundoscopy is done to rule out retinoblastoma, and any other pathology
  • The angle of squint is measured and full spectacle correction is ordered for constant use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forced ductions test: Used to check if the eye muscles move normally or are restricted, more relevant in cases where physical obstruction or muscle entrapment is suspected.

 

Option B. Examination under anesthesia: May be necessary for a comprehensive examination in uncooperative children, but it is not the first step.

 

Option D. Examination of fundus: Important for ruling out intraocular causes of squint such as retinoblastoma, but it follows the refractive assessment in priority.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first management step for a child presenting with a convergent squint is to test for refractive errors. This helps to identify any need for optical correction which might resolve or reduce the squint, thereby improving the visual development and alignment of the eyes.

choices.text: Routine Ha & E

questions.text: Identify the histopathological image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amyloidosis

 

The given image demonstrates Congo red stain showing Pink red appearance under normal light. This stain is used in diagnosis of Amyloidosis.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Elastic fibers: Elastic fibers can be demonstrated by Verhoeff-van Gieson Stain.

 

 

Option B. Routine H & E: Routine H & E is done by Hematoxylin and eosin stain. The hematoxylin stains cell nuclei a purplish blue, and eosin stains the extracellular matrix and cytoplasm pink.

 

 

Option D. Collagen: Collagen can be demonstrated by Masson trichrome stain. It gives blue color to the collagen, black color to nuclei and red to muscle present.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congo red staining, showing pink-red deposits under normal light, is characteristic of amyloid and is a key diagnostic tool for amyloidosis.

questions.text: A patient alleges negligence by a surgeon and sues him for the same. In case of professional misconduct, the patient's records on demand should be provided within? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 3 days

 

In case of professional misconduct, the patient's records on demand should be provided within 72 hours/ 3 days.

 

The treating doctor has to maintain the medical records of the patients for a period of three years as per the regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MEDICAL RECORDS

 

1. Duration of retention of records –

  • Digital Records – 10 years
  • Hard copy – 
  • OPD patients: 3 years
  • Indoor patients: 3 years
  • MLC: 10 years

2. Time to provide records – 3 days

3. What if records not maintained – punished for infamous conduct

questions.text: Match the following drugs with the organism they are used for? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-F

 

The correct matches based on the given drugs and organisms:

 

  1. Praziquantal: This drug is primarily used for the treatment of flukes (except liver fluke) and tapeworms (except dog tapeworm). Therefore, the correct match for Praziquantal is D (Tapeworms).
  2. Di Ethyl Carbamezine: This drug is the drug of choice for the treatment of filariasis, making A (Filaria) the correct match.
  3. Nitazoxanide: This drug is used for Cryptosporidium and also for Giardia. However, the drug of choice for Giardia is metronidazole or tinidazole, but Nitazoxanide is also effective against Giardia. Therefore, the correct match for Nitazoxanide is B (Giardia).
  4. Mebendazole: This drug is used for treating various nematodes, including Ascaris lumbricoides. Therefore, the correct match for Mebendazole is F (Ascaris lumbricoides).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Drug of choice for treatment of flukes (except liver fluke) and tapeworms (except dog tapeworm) is Praziquantal.
    • Drug of choice for treatment of liver fluke is triclabendazole.
    • Drug of choice for dog tapeworm (Echinococcus) is albendazole
  • Drug of choice for all nematodes (see exceptions below) is albendazole (or Mebendazole)
    • Drug of choice for treatment of filariasis is Diethylcarbamazine.
    • Drug of choice for treatment of Onchocerca and Strongyloides is ivermectin.
  • Nitazoxanide: DOC for Cryptosporidium and also used for Giardia (DOC is metronidazole and tinidazole)

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/907

questions.text: By which mechanism does gene repair occur when mediated by CRISPR-Cas9?(AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-Homologous End joining

 

Common repair mechanism in mammalian cells.

 

  • Error-prone: It can introduce insertions or deletions (indels) at the cut site.
  • This mechanism is frequently used in CRISPR-Cas9 to disrupt gene function (gene knock-out).

 

Many clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats (CRISPR)-CRISPR-associated protein 9 (Cas9)-based genome editing technologies take advantage of Cas nucleases to induce DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) at desired locations within a genome. Further processing of the DSBs by the cellular DSB repair machinery is then necessary to introduce desired mutations, sequence insertions, or gene deletions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision: This repair mechanism corrects single-base lesions that do not significantly distort the DNA helix, typically involving the removal of damaged bases by glycosylases followed by endonuclease action.

 

Option C. Homologous End Joining: This term is not commonly used in the context of DSB repair. The correct term would be Homologous Recombination (HR), which is an accurate repair mechanism but not the predominant one in CRISPR-Cas9-mediated repairs.

 

Option D. Mismatch repair: This mechanism corrects base-pair mismatches and small insertion/deletion loops formed during DNA replication and recombination, but it is not primarily involved in repairing DSBs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRISPR-Cas9 mediated gene repair primarily occurs through Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ), an error-prone repair process that ligates broken DNA ends together, often resulting in small insertions or deletions at the repair site.

questions.text: All of the following oncogenic viruses can integrate with the human genome to initiate carcinogenesis except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HTLV

 

  • HTLV - Human T cell lymphotropic virus causes microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.
  • Oncoviruses are classified as direct or indirect carcinogens, although some overlap exists between the distinction. Direct carcinogenic viruses possess viral oncogenes that directly contribute to neoplastic cellular transformation, whereas indirect carcinogens cause chronic inflammation, which can lead to oncogenic transformation.
  • DNA tumor viruses encode viral oncoproteins which may become integrated into the host cell chromosome.
  • RNA viruses are known to cause microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HPV (Human Papillomavirus):

 

  • Mechanism: HPV integrates its DNA into the host genome, leading to the production of oncoproteins E6 and E7, which inactivate tumor suppressor genes p53 and Rb. This disruption of tumor suppressor pathways contributes to the development of cancers such as cervical cancer.
  • Example: Cervical cancer is a well-documented outcome of HPV infection, particularly with high-risk strains like HPV 16 and 18.

 

Option B. HBV (Hepatitis B Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: HBV can integrate its DNA into the host genome, contributing to hepatocellular carcinoma. The integration can lead to genomic instability and the insertional activation of oncogenes or inactivation of tumor suppressor genes.
  • Example: Chronic hepatitis B infection is a major risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Option D. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: EBV can integrate into the host genome and produce latent proteins that drive cell proliferation and prevent apoptosis. The viral proteins LMP1 and EBNA2 are key players in this process, contributing to the development of various cancers, including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Example: EBV is strongly associated with Burkitt's lymphoma, particularly in endemic areas such as sub-Saharan Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oncogenic DNA and RNA Viruses:

 

  • Oncogenic DNA Viruses:
    • EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus)
    • HBV (Hepatitis B Virus)
    • HPV (Human Papillomavirus)
    • HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus-8)
    • MCPyV (Merkel Cell Polyomavirus)
  • Oncogenic RNA Viruses:
    • HCV (Hepatitis C Virus)
    • HTLV-1 (Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus-1)

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman was taken by her neighbour to the emergency department after an incident involving her husband. She reported that during a domestic altercation, her husband swung an axe at her left arm. Upon examination, a significant injury was observed on her upper left arm. The wound appeared deep, with jagged and irregular edges. The surrounding area showed signs of bruising. Based on the clinical scenario, what type of wound is likely to be present on the patient's upper left arm? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chop wound 

 

A heavy object which is relatively sharp edged, e.g. axe produces chop wounds. Chop wounds have features of both sharp and blunt force injuries. They are characterized by deep, jagged, and irregular edges with surrounding bruising.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incised wound:

 

  • Produced by lighter weapons like knife, blades etc.
  • Margins are not contused and abraded. 
  • Destruction of underlying tissues is less as compared to cop wound.

 

Option C. Lacerated wound:

 

  • Lacerations can result from accidents, falls, or impact with blunt objects.
  • Lacerated wounds are not clean cut, whereas incised and chop wounds are clean cut.

 

Option D. Abrasion:  In abrasions only the superficial skin is damaged. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cut laceration / chop wounds: 

 

  • Produced by a heavy object which is relatively sharp edged, E.g. axe, chopper
    • It has features of both blunt force (bruised and abraded margins, irregular margins) and sharp force (clean margins)
    • A deep and wide cut over the body tissues.
    • Marked destruction of underlying tissues
    • Below image shows chop wound by axe:

questions.text: Blood supply for the red shaded area in the given image is a branch of which artery? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vertebral artery

 

 

 

The red shaded area in the given image indicates a portion of the lateral medulla. The blood supply to this area is provided by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery. This area is typically involved in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

 

  • Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA): This artery is a branch of the vertebral artery and supplies the lateral part of the medulla and the inferior part of the cerebellum. Damage to this artery can lead to lateral medullary syndrome, characterized by various neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior cerebellar artery: This artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and does not supply the lateral medulla.

 

Option B. Posterior cerebral artery: This artery primarily supplies the occipital lobe and parts of the temporal lobe, not the lateral medulla.

 

Option D. Basilar artery: While the basilar artery gives rise to the superior cerebellar artery and the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, it does not directly supply the lateral medulla. The vertebral arteries, which form the basilar artery, give rise to PICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery, supplies the lateral medulla. Damage to this artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).
